public-advisory.Title: It is now winter in Mount Robson Park. Ensure you are checking weather and avalanche conditions prior to recreating in the park.
public-advisory.Description:
Winter Use of the Berg Lake Trail
  • Reservations or day passes are not required for winter day trips or overnight stays
  • There are no fees collected for winter camping
  • Dogs are only allowed on the Berg Lake Trail for day hikes
  • Fires are prohibited along the trail, except at Hargreaves Shelter (wood supply not guaranteed)
  • Winter conditions are to be expected:
    • check the weather and avalanche forecast prior to leaving; when travelling on this trail you are in avalanche territory the first slide path starts between km 1 and 2 bring suitable gear;
    • carry a satellite communication device in case of emergency; and
    • leave a trip plan with friends or family and follow winter recreation guidelines set out by Adventure Smart
  • Follow all COVID-19 guidelines set out by the Provincial Health Officer

public-advisory.Title: Hazard warning - winter conditions
public-advisory.Description:
Narrow winding mountain road, expect snow, ice and steep grades.
Must use winter tires, must carry chains.

Chains must be installed to access the upper parking lot at Diamond Head (Red Heather, Elfin Lakes), and the parking lot at Rubble Creek (Garibaldi Lake, Taylor Meadows).

Vehicles blocking snow removal equipment on road will be towed at owners’ expense.

Grader requires minimum 20 feet of road width.

Vehicles are advised not to park on Ring Creek Road as they may be subject to Municipal Towing.

Chains are mandatory beyond the chain up area, as per posted signage or direction by park staff.

Failure to comply will result in a $115 fine and or eviction from the park.

public-advisory.Title: White-Nose Syndrome
public-advisory.Description:
White-nose Syndrome is a fungal disease that has been linked to the mass die-off of hibernating bats in Eastern North America – it poses a significant threat to bats of the west and British Columbia. There is evidence that humans have accelerated the spread through entering caves with contaminated clothing, gear or equipment. To help prevent WNS from taking hold in B.C., the Province is making investments in bat conservation projects.

To ensure the protection of bats and their habitat in this park, BC Parks strongly advises that personal caving gear that has been used anywhere east of the Rockies not be used in B.C. Also, before entering caves in B.C, cavers and visitors should consult the provincial WNS website, which includes a link to a Decontamination Protocol for Mines and Caves.

Learn more about white-nose syndrome

public-advisory.Title: Please be mindful while visiting
public-advisory.Description:
Tatshenshini-Alsek Provincial Park is open and while visiting the park, we ask you to please be mindful of the following before heading out to explore:

  • Snowmobilers, please review where snowmobiling is permitted within the park [PDF].
  • Out of province snowmobilers riding on crown land in BC need to be aware of Section 7 of the ORV Regulations, and must carry photo ID and proof of ownership of their snowmobile at all times.
  • Events are not allowed. As of March 15th, outside gatherings of up to 10 individuals can occur if those in attendance are within your bubble, masks are worn and social distancing requirements are maintained. See the current BC COVID-19 guidelines.
  • Staying safe in the backcountry is your responsibility; outdoor enthusiasts need to be thoroughly prepared every time they venture out:
    • educate yourself on avalanche safety and how to read the terrain;
    • check the avalanche forecast prior to departing to ensure conditions are safe;
    • make sure everybody in your group knows what to do if one occurs;
    • leave a trip plan with friends or family; and
    • always carry essential gear:
      • a shovel;
      • probe;
      • avalanche transceiver; and
  • Please be aware that COVID-19 has impacted search and rescue associations reducing their capacity and ability to respond. Practice an abundance of caution, and refrain from high risk activities, or simply, stay home.
  • Enforcement will be present over the Easter long weekend.

public-advisory.Title: Help protect Cathedral’s Mountain Goats

Goats that become habituated to these attractants can pose a risk to people and may need to be removed or destroyed. Understand what you must do to protect mountain goats and keep them wild.

public-advisory.Title: Upcoming closures of Wade Road trails in Tsútswecw Provincial Park for project work completion
public-advisory.Description:
In order to facilitate completion C7îstkteñ Winter House project within Tsútswecw Provincial Park, public access to the Wade Road Hiking Trails will be intermittently closed. Construction activities both on, and to and from the site will make the area unsafe for public use. For specific dates and closure times, refer to signage posted at the wade road trailhead. Please obey all posted signs and closure notifications. Future updates will be posted on this webpage for your reference.

Your cooperation is greatly appreciated while we complete these facility upgrades.

  • Licence Plate Program (LPP) sponsored C7îstkteñ Winter Home Project

    This is a partnership initiative between Little Shuswap Lake Band, Niskonlith Indian Band, Adams Lake Indian Band and BC Parks and is funded through the BC Provincial Licence Plate Program (LPP hereafter). The C7îstkteñ Winter House Project honours the unique and deeply meaningful Indigenous culture and long occupation history of this area. Indigenous use at this site stretches back millennia. The enhancement will provide opportunities for visitors to experience the vast natural and cultural history within Tsútswecw Park.

    Once completed, the facility will be made available for use by Indigenous Peoples and Park Visitors alike. Use will include the hosting of school groups, educational gatherings, special events, and celebrations.

    The projects primary goal is to continue building strong Indigenous Partnerships with local First Nation communities and the Secwepemc Nation as a whole. The facility enhancement will provide a safe place for both Indigenous Members and Park Visitors to gather and experience the vast natural beauty and cultural history of the Area.

public-advisory.Title: Gold Creek Campground closed for winter camping
public-advisory.Description:
Gold Creek Campground is closed for winter camping until further notice due to hazardous weather conditions.

There is 10cm of snow in the forecast as well as temperatures well below seasonal normal accompanied by strong outflow winds over the next several days. Camping in these conditions is hazardous due to the potential for falling trees and branches, and the possibility of getting trapped in the park by trees across the road.

Golden Ears Park road remains open to vehicle traffic as of now, but we will re-evaluate tomorrow morning after the temperature drops significantly overnight.

  • Parnassus Cree
These can be avoided by traveling via Taylor Meadows.

public-advisory.Title: Trail closure

public-advisory.Title: Walking trails between campgrounds are closed until further notice
public-advisory.Description: A recent and major landslide (Dec. 30, 2020) sent trees and massive amounts of debris across the trail and into the lake. The silt bluff above the trails is both unstable and unpredictable. Landslide events and recently deposited debris could injure, bury or kill persons travelling through the accumulation zone, so the trail remains unsafe and closed to recreational use. Geotechnical Engineers are assessing the movement and will make recommendations on the future of the trail. BC Parks understands the value of this trail to park visitors, but can re-open only once the area is declared safe.

public-advisory.Title: Ongoing environmental spill response
public-advisory.Description:
Notice to Park Visitors

Please be advised that there is an ongoing environmental spill response on Zuciarte Channel in Bligh Island Park as a result of a historic shipwreck. An Emergency Zone has been established by the Canadian Coast Guard for all mariners as per the link below:
http://www.spillresponsebc.ca/marinenotice/

Please avoid this designated area.

For more information on the Bligh Island Shipwreck please see the link below:
http://www.spillresponsebc.ca/

public-advisory.Title: Scheduled power outage Jan 14
public-advisory.Description:
BC Hydro has scheduled a power outage at Porteau Cove Provincial Park January 14th from 8:00AM – 4:30PM in order to complete necessary maintenance.

We ask that if you see BC Hydro crews or contractors, please respect social distancing measures and maintain a physical distance of at least two metres. We apologize for the inconvenience and thank you for your patience.

public-advisory.Title: Winter Parking – Coquihalla Summit Recreation Area
public-advisory.Description:
Visitors may notice parking signs at the Highway 5 Zopkios Brake Check area. The Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure advises there are no new parking restrictions. The previous signs were becoming weathered and required replacement.

For safety reasons, the signs are intended to prevent commercial vehicles from parking and congesting the Zopkios Brake Check area which significantly impacts the maintenance contractors ability to operate during storm cycles.

Enforcement of parking by passenger vehicles isn’t planned as long as parking does not impede traffic or winter maintenance activities.

BC Parks and MOTI are working together to explore long term parking and access improvements at the Coquihalla Summit Recreation Area.

Please refer to the following link for some helpful visuals created by the Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure in an effort to help clarify exactly where adventure seekers CAN and CAN’T park along BC Highway 5, within this area.
Coquihalla Parking [PDF]

public-advisory.Title: Clearwater Valley Road groomed
public-advisory.Description: Clearwater Valley Road groomed from Yellow gate (intersection with Helmcken Falls road) to Clearwater Lake. Trackset to Red Springs (7km one way).

public-advisory.Title: Park is open for the cross-country ski season
public-advisory.Description:
Fuel management work is complete for the season and the park is now re-opened for winter cross-country use. Day-Use warming huts are open, following COVID-19 protocols:
  • Facility is for day-use only: overnight stays are not permitted
  • Provincial Health Officer COVID-19 protocols must be followed
  • Wear a mask and maintain a minimum of 2 meters physical distancing except with members of the same household
  • This facility is un-serviced: it is not cleaned and cleaning products are not provided
  • Visitors are responsible for their own cleaning and sanitation
  • Maximum capacity for the main warming hut is 4 people, with a maximum duration of 20 minutes to allow use by others

public-advisory.Title: To protect the health of our visitors and staff, the following facilities closed
public-advisory.Description:
Kaslo Lake cook shelter
Gibson Lake, Silverspray, Woodbury, & Slocan Chief cabins

public-advisory.Title: Camp host opportunity for Croteau Lake
public-advisory.Description: BC Parks is currently accepting applications for camp hosts at the Croteau Lake Groupsite for the 2021 season. Basic information can be found in the brochure. Host duties may be adjusted for the 2021 season due to COVID-19. For further information please contact james.godfrey@gov.bc.ca.

public-advisory.Title: Hazard warning -- winter road conditions
public-advisory.Description:
Narrow winding mountain road, expect snow, ice and steep grades.
Must use winter tires, must carry chains.

Chains must be installed to access the upper parking lot at Diamond Head (Red Heather, Elfin Lakes), and the parking lot at Rubble Creek (Garibaldi Lake, Taylor Meadows).

Vehicles blocking snow removal equipment on road will be towed at owners’ expense.

Grader requires minimum 20 feet of road width.

Vehicles are advised not to park on Ring Creek Road as they may be subject to Municipal Towing.

Chains are mandatory beyond the chain up area, as per posted signage or direction by park staff.

Failure to comply will result in a $115 fine and or eviction from the park.

public-advisory.Title: Improvements to French Beach Provincial Park have now been completed
public-advisory.Description: Recent upgrades have improved the convenience, visitor satisfaction, and accessibility throughout the campground and day-use areas of the park. Eleven new fully accessible toilets have replaced all the existing toilets in these locations. In addition, all of the campsite driveways have been widened to allow easier and safer access for larger trailers and RV’s to each site.

public-advisory.Title: Morton Lake Park will be inaccessible from Nov 25 to Jan 11, 2020
public-advisory.Description: The Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development is in the process of providing much needed road work and rehabilitation on the Morton Lake Forest Road accessing Morton Lake Park.  Due to heavy equipment on site through this period the road is closed to all traffic.

public-advisory.Title: Golden Ears Park Road closed
public-advisory.Description: Golden Ears Park road is closed due to hazardous road conditions. Visitors can park in the Main Horse Corral parking lot and walk into the park. There is no vehicle access to Gold Creek Campground at this time. This information will be updated when the road reopens.

Park Access and Traffic
  • Cypress Park is expected to experience unprecedented demand for access over the winter holiday season.
  • All park visitors should check @Cypress_Park_PO on Twitter for up-to-date traffic and park access info before planning your trip to the park and while on route to the park.
  • Digital message boards will be posted on the access road with live updates to notify of current traffic conditions. Visitors should heed these signs and if the signs say the lots are full, park visitors should plan to come to the park another time.
  • Free public parking is available in Parking Lot 3B. Parking fees will be implemented this year in the Nordic Area Lot 4 and in Lots 1,2, and 3A and adjacent roadsides in the Downhill Area. These fees will be charged only to vehicles whose occupants have not pre-purchased a ticket or Pass for planned activities within the Alpine or Nordic Ski Area Boundaries.
COVID-19 Safety Plan at Cypress Provincial Park:
  • All park visitors must follow the Provincial Health Officer COVID-19 safety guidelines. Visitors must wear a mask in common spaces, stay 2 meters apart, hand sanitizer often, and do not come to the park if you are feeling unwell. Please see BC Parks COVID-19 information for park visitors.
  • Access to the Cypress Mountain Resorts facilities are limited to ski pass holders to ensure adherence to physical distancing requirements.
  • Park visitors may use the Brown Bag room, Black Mountain Lodge washrooms, or the additional portable toilets provided at trail heads and in parking lot 3B.
  • Pack a lunch as there are no food and beverage services available for non-ski hill pass holders.
  • A reminder that all park visitors need a backcountry waiver tag to access the park. These are available in the Brown Bag room at the Black Mountain Lodge.
  • BC Parks will have park ranger staff on site to assist in managing traffic, and to provide education and compliance to ensure that park visitors are safe and are respecting the PHO guidelines and COVID-19 safety plans. Cypress Mountain Resort’s COVID-19 Safety Plan and BC Parks COVID-19 Visitor Information.
Travelling through the Backcountry Access Corridor
To access the Black Mountain Plateau and Bowen Lookout Winter Trail (Yew Lake), you need to travel through the Backcountry Access Corridor (BAC).
  • Get your Yellow Tag (release of liability) before recreating on the Yew Lake trails and beyond. Yellow tags are available at the Black Mountain Lodge.
  • Washrooms are available for backcountry park visitors in the Black Mountain Lodge.
  • Follow the marked route through the downhill ski area to the winter trails.
  • Backcountry Winter Trails Map
Winter Safety
  • Refer to the know before you go section to learn about parking, closures and other information.
  • Check the avalanche conditions at avalanche.ca and bring the appropriate equipment.
  • Prepare your vehicle for winter travel.
  • Plan your trip around daylight hours for warmth and light.
  • Wear warm layers & appropriate footwear.
  • Make a Trip Plan (AdventureSmart has a great app) and let a friend know your plans.

Park Access and Traffic Management

Mt. Seymour Park is expected to experience unprecedented demand for access over the winter holiday season.

In good weather on weekends and holidays, the parking lots will reach capacity before 9 AM.

All park visitors should check @Seymour_Park_PO on Twitter for up-to-date traffic and park access info before planning your trip to the park and while on route to the park.

Digital message boards will be posted on the access road with live updates to notify park visitors when the parking lots are full. When lots are full, visitors will be turned away. Visitors should heed these signs and if the signs say the lots are full, park visitors should plan to come to the park another time.

COVID-19 Safety Plan at Mount Seymour Provincial Park

All park visitors must follow the Provincial Health Officer COVID-19 safety guidelines. Visitors must wear a mask in common spaces, stay 2 meters apart, hand sanitizer often, and do not come to the park if you are feeling unwell.

  • BC Parks COVID-19 Visitor Information

BC Parks will have park ranger staff on site to assist in managing traffic, and to provide education and compliance to ensure that park visitors are safe and are respecting the PHO guidelines and COVID-19 safety plans.

  • Mt Seymour Resort COVID-19 Winter Protocols
  • BC Parks COVID-19 Visitor Information
Winter Safety
  • Refer to the Know Before You Go section to learn about parking, closures and other information.
  • Check the avalanche conditions at avalanche.ca and bring the appropriate equipment.
  • Prepare your vehicle for winter travel.
  • Plan your trip around daylight hours for warmth and light.
  • Wear warm layers & appropriate footwear.
  • Make a Trip Plan (AdventureSmart has a great app) and let a friend know your plans.

public-advisory.Title: Osprey Campground/Group Use and Day Use area and parking lot is open for the winter
public-advisory.Description: Plowed winter access to Kokanee Creek Park is by the Osprey campground/ Group Use and Day use road (to the south west of the Nature Center). The main Park entrance is not plowed and is closed for road safety at this time. Winter conditions may be icy, please take care.

public-advisory.Title: Pets must be on leash at all times
public-advisory.Description:
Kokanee Creek estuary area is important habitat for migratory and resident waterfowl and shorebirds. Thanks for doing your part to help sensitive wildlife by keeping your dog on a leash.

Pets/domestic animals must be on a leash at all times and are not allowed in beach areas. This applies year-round. A dog beach is beside the boat launch at the north-east end of the park. Park visitors are responsible for their behaviour and must dispose of their excrement.

public-advisory.Title: King Warming hut open for day use with limited capacity
public-advisory.Description:
The King Warming hut in Wells Gray is open for day use with the maximum capacity of 2 person or only the members of the same household. To allow use by others, spend maximum 20 minutes inside.

Provincial Health Officer Covid-19 protocols must be followed. Masks must be worn in all indoor public spaces in British Columbia.

Facility is un-serviced: it is not cleaned and cleaning products are not supplied. Visitors are responsible for their own cleaning and sanitation. Garbage and personal items must be packed out.

public-advisory.Title: Cheakamus Lake Road closure
public-advisory.Description: Cheakamus Lake Road (AKA Cheakamus Forest Service Road) is currently closed to public access for forest fire fuel treatment work. Access to the park via the Cheakamus Lake trailhead will re-open in the Spring

public-advisory.Title: Day use area open through winter season
public-advisory.Description:
We are happy to have a new volunteer partnership agreement in place between Tourism Pemberton Destination Marketing Association, Daniel Schranz Contracting Ltd., and BC Parks, for the benefit of the entire community and all park visitors. This collaborative agreement allows access to Nairn Falls Provincial Park day use area throughout the winter months.

Public access to this area will be allowed six days per week Access to the site will be closed on Sunday afternoon at 1700 hours (5:00pm) through to Monday afternoon at 1700 hours (5:00pm) in order to accommodate another BC Parks volunteer partnership with Spud Valley Nordics Association (SVNA). SVNA operate their programs on Monda

Public are asked to please stay off of the groomed ski tracks at all times, to follow signage and to stay on designated recreational access trails to avoid damaging the Nordic trails. There is No Overnight Parking allowed in a day use area. If overnight parking occurs, BC Parks will return to a closed gate operational model. This is a trial agreement for this winter season of 2020-21.

public-advisory.Title: Trans Mountain Expansion Project Construction
public-advisory.Description:
Trans Mountain Expansion Project construction is now underway in the Recreation Area. During the winter season visitors may notice workers in the area. In the summer visitors may notice increased construction activities including clearing, grading, heli-logging, trenching and pipe installation. All construction activities have received appropriate permits and authorizations.

All trails remain open although short detours may be in place during the summer. Please follow the instructions of any onsite personnel. For more information visit transmountain.com/coquihalla or contact info@transmountain.com / 1.866.514.6700.

public-advisory.Title: Backcountry skiers – please call for safety information before heading out
public-advisory.Description:
Whistler Blackcomb Mountain Operations requests all visitors skiing into their boundaries from the backcountry areas to call the number below and get the latest safety information. Mountain Operations continues to make all areas within their resort as safe as possible for all visitors. Calling this number will ensure you are not unknowingly entering into an unsafe area.

Ski Area Boundary Status: (604) 905-2324. You will hear a voice mail tree; 1 for the Whistler boundaries, 2 for the Blackcomb boundaries, 3 is for the weather forecast.

public-advisory.Title: BC Parks has reassessed the closure and the closure area has been amended
public-advisory.Description:
In May 2019, BC Parks closed the Nlh xten/Cerise Creek Conservancy after two landslides from Joffre Peak heavily impacted the Cerise Creek watershed within the Conservancy.

BC Parks has reassessed the closure and the closure area has been amended. Public access is not permitted within the immediate slide path as outlined in red on the map posted on the Nlh xten/Cerise Creek Conservancy website. There is one temporary route located at the midpoint of the landslide track. This route is unmaintained and is not a designated trail. The time crossing the path must be minimized. The remaining areas of the Conservancy are now open to public access.

The Keith Flavelle Hut (Keith’s Hut) is outside the closure area, however, the Hut remains closed due to PHO COVID-19 restrictions.

Signage has been posted at the trailheads and on the conservancy website.

BC Parks will be conducting a further assessment of the closure area in 2021.
public-advisory.Note: This didn’t have a park assigned and was duplicated

public-advisory.Title: Winter Safety
Police Meadows Cabin is closed
public-advisory.Description: Police Meadows Cabin is currently closed due to COVID-19. Please continue to monitor this web page for ongoing updates related to facility closures and impacts due to COVID-19.

public-advisory.Title: Surprise Creek Cabin is closed
public-advisory.Description: Surprise Creek Cabin is currently closed due to COVID-19. Please continue to monitor this web page for ongoing updates related to facility closures and impacts due to COVID-19.

public-advisory.Title: Voluntary winter closure area to protect critical wolverine habitat
public-advisory.Description:
Voluntary Winter Closure Area – to protect critical wolverine habitat (4.4 km2 polygon within Kokanee Glacier Park). Thank you for observing this voluntary closure by not accessing this area of the park from January 15 to May 15, 2021.
  • Voluntary Winter Closure Area Map [PDF]

public-advisory.Title: Trail washout Sombrio River Suspension Bridge to West Sombrio Campsite
public-advisory.Description: Due to recent storm surges and king tides along the Juan de Fuca Marine Trail there is a significant wash-out west of the Sombrio River Suspension Bridge to the West Sombrio Campsite. This section of trail is currently not passable.

public-advisory.Title: Spahats Falls parking lot and trail open for winter use
public-advisory.Description: Spahats Falls parking lot and trail plowed.

public-advisory.Title: Road closure at Diamond Head Dec. 8, 2020
public-advisory.Description: Visitors to Diamond Head, Red Heather, and Elfin Lakes, please be advised that on Tuesday, Dec. 8th from 10:00am until 12:00pm, the road will be closed at the chain up area. Please plan your visits accordingly

public-advisory.Title: Cabins closed
public-advisory.Description: Itcha & Kettle cabin in Itcha Ilgachuz Park will be closed for the 2020/21 winter season due to COVID-19 restrictions.

public-advisory.Title: Travel to park not advised
public-advisory.Description: Due to a significant wind and rain event on November 17, 2020, facilities in the park have been impacted making some trails impassable. At this time, there is no access beyond 14.5Km (Hansen Lagoon) to Nels Bight and the Cape Scott Lighthouse. Assessments are underway to determine extent of damage to other facilities on the North Coast Trail. The full extent of damage in all areas of the park are unknown at this time. Please use extreme caution if visiting the park during this time and continue to check back for updates.

public-advisory.Title: Eastern beach access stairs closed
public-advisory.Description: The Eastern beach access stairs are currently closed due to re-construction. Please use the western access for accessing the beach. No other trails are closed at this time.

public-advisory.Title: Widgeon Lake trail closed
public-advisory.Description: The trail to Widgeon Lake has been closed due to a failing crossing at Hanging Creek. Please do not attempt accessing Widgeon Lake via the Widgeon Lake trail at this time.

public-advisory.Title: Water facilities closed during cold weather
public-advisory.Description:
During periods of freezing temperatures, all above ground water sources such as the drinking fountains, water taps and the sani-station will be shut down and will remain off until temperatures rise above 0°C.

This most often means water taps and the sani-station are turned off and closed at night and turned on the following day, late morning, once temperatures rise above freezing.

Service interruptions may last longer during cold snaps.

Water is accessible at the day-use washroom building and the frost-free tap outside the campground shower building (closed during the winter).

Access may be limited, so we ask that campers plan ahead and bring a suitable supply of potable water.

public-advisory.Title: Reservations required during peak season
public-advisory.Description:
Reservations are required during peak season (June 26 – September 30) for all overnight stays in the core area of Mount Assiniboine Provincial Park (Magog Lake and Og Lake campgrounds).

  • Mount Assiniboine Reservation FAQ

Please check current snowpack conditions before reserving a tent pad at the beginning of peak season. Snow melt typically does not occur at Magog campground until mid July. The Assiniboine Lodge webcam is a good reference to gauge snowpack at Magog campground.

public-advisory.Title: Bridge damaged on Shingle Spit/Ford Cove trail
public-advisory.Description: A bridge along the Shingle Spit/Ford Cove trail was badly damaged in a recent storm event and is currently closed due to safety concerns

public-advisory.Title: Visitors encouraged to wear masks while travelling through congested areas
public-advisory.Description: Mount Seymour Provincial Park is a popular destination for winter recreation, and everyone must take precautions for a fun and safe trip to the park. All visitors are encouraged to wear a mask while travelling through congested areas including parking lots, at the trailheads, and at viewing areas. As per PHO regulations, all park visitors must wear a mask when inside any park facility. Be sure to stay 2 meters apart, and don’t forget to bring your own hand sanitizer and hand sanitize often. All park visitors must adhere to the Mt Seymour Resort COVID-19 winter protocols when transiting through the ski base area or using any facilities

public-advisory.Title: Visitors encouraged to wear masks while travelling through congested areas
public-advisory.Description: Cypress Provincial Park is a popular destination for winter recreation, and everyone must take precautions for a fun and safe trip to the park. All visitors are encouraged to wear a mask while travelling through congested areas including parking lots, at the trailheads, and at viewing areas. As per PHO regulations, all park visitors must wear a mask when inside any park facility. Be sure to stay 2 meters apart, and don’t forget to bring your own hand sanitizer and hand sanitize often. All park visitors must adhere to the Cypress Mountain Resort COVID-19 Operational Plan when transiting through the ski base area, which includes mandatory mask wearing.

public-advisory.Title: Angel Springs parking lot and Myra Bailout Trail areas closed until further notice
public-advisory.Description: The Angel Springs parking lot and Myra Bailout Trail areas are closed as of December 1 to allow for continuation of an ecosystem restoration project. There will be equipment operating in this area and on Little White Forest Service Road. Please obey all on-site signage and stay out of the work area until further notice.

public-advisory.Title: Fuel management projects in West Arm Park this fall
public-advisory.Description:
Please be advised that BC Parks is conducting fuel management projects in West Arm Park this fall (September to December). To ensure public safety during these treatments, there will be recreational access closures associated with the projects.

  • 12.7-hectare hand treatment along Lasca Roa. There will be no recreational access beyond the gate as of September 1st, until mid-December.
  • 15.4-hectare mechanical treatment at the end of Lasca Road. There will be no recreational access beyond the gate as of September 1st, until mid-December.

Please obey all informational signage posted on site and please check this website often for the latest updates.

For more information, please call 250 489-9211.

public-advisory.Title: Majerus Warming Hut open for day use in Wells Gray
public-advisory.Description:
The Majerus Warming hut in Wells Gray is open for day use with a maximum capacity of 4 people at any one time. Provincial Health Officer Covid-19 protocols must be followed. Maintain a minimum of 2 meters physical distancing except with members of your own household.

Facility is un-serviced: it is not cleaned and cleaning products are not supplied. Visitors are responsible for their own cleaning and sanitation. Garbage and personal items must be packed out.

public-advisory.Title: Visitors encouraged to wear masks while travelling through congested areas
public-advisory.Description: Cypress Provincial Park is a popular destination for winter recreation, and everyone must take precautions for a fun and safe trip to the park. All visitors are encouraged to wear a mask while travelling through congested areas including parking lots, at the trailheads, and at viewing areas. As per PHO regulations, all park visitors must wear a mask when inside any park facility.  Be sure to stay 2 meters apart, and don’t forget to bring your own hand sanitizer and hand sanitize often. All park visitors must adhere to the Cypress Mountain Resort COVID-19 Operational Plan when transiting through the ski base area, which includes mandatory mask wearing.

All visitors are encouraged to wear a mask while travelling through congested areas including parking lots, at the trailheads, and at viewing areas. As per PHO regulations, all park visitors must wear a mask when inside any park facility.  Be sure to stay 2 meters apart, and don’t forget to bring your own hand sanitizer and hand sanitize often. public-advisory.Title: Contact tracing requirement for campers
public-advisory.Description: Due to the current Island Health order requiring contract tracing information be provided for all campers in the Island Health region, please be aware of this requirement in park and complete the provided contact tracing form along with your in-park registration and fees. If you are able to complete this in advance or are staying in a campground that is unmaintained, please submit this form to BCPContactTrace@gov.bc.ca.

public-advisory.Title: Empress bypass trail closed
public-advisory.Description: Empress Bypass trail will continue to be closed for trail maintenance until Friday, Nov. 27. Thank you for your patience.

public-advisory.Title: Please be properly equipped for winter road conditions
public-advisory.Description:
Park users are reminded to be properly equipped for winter driving and road conditions. Roads in the park are not plowed or sanded in the winter.

Be prepared for snow and ice. Carrying tire chains is recommended.

Winter Tire, chain, and traction device requirements October 1, 2020 – April 30, 2021:

  • Passenger Vehicle-Tire and Chain Requirements
  • Recreational Vehicle &Tailer Tire and Chain Requirements

public-advisory.Title: Caution - Trails and parking lots not maintained during winter
public-advisory.Description: Trails and parking lots are not maintained in the winter. You may encounter deep snow, ice and slippery conditions. Micro spikes or snowshoes are strongly recommended. Use at your own risk.

public-advisory.Title: Caution - Icy conditions
public-advisory.Description: During cold conditions, ice may form. Trail may be slippery. Watch for falling ice and debris.

public-advisory.Title: Caution - Winter conditions
public-advisory.Description: Trail and parking lots are not maintained in the winter. You may encounter deep snow, ice and slippery conditions. Micro spikes or snowshoes are strongly recommended.

public-advisory.Title: Caution - Frozen lakes extremely dangerous
public-advisory.Description:
Frozen lakes are extremely dangerous and ice thickness is NOT monitored. Our recommendation is to stay off the ice.

Should you choose to proceed onto the lake this is at your own risk. If you would like to learn more about the dangers of ice, please read this information on ice safety.

public-advisory.Title: Construction and access notice
public-advisory.Description:
BC Parks will be performing improvements on the Stump Lake parking lots, commencing Nov. 12. The work will last approximately two weeks, and there will be no parking at Stump Lake during that period. Please park in the main day use area by taking the first right on the Alice Lake Road towards Alice Lake, and be aware of the construction equipment when accessing the Four Lakes Trail.

For hikers and bikers who would like to use the gravel road beyond Stump Lake lot, please park in the main day use area and hike or bike through the campground. Please stop prior to passing the construction site and ensure that the operator permits you to pass before proceeding.

Thank you for your patience and understanding.

public-advisory.Title: Significant hazard exists at the outflow to Ross Lake. Rainmaker Trail closed until further notice.
Road closure at Goldstream Campground
public-advisory.Description: Road Closure for hydro tree work at Goldstream Campground on Nov. 25 (9:30am-1pm). Golden Gate Road will be closed and there will be no vehicle or pedestrian access (in or out) during this time.

public-advisory.Title: Park will be inaccessible Nov. 25 to Dec. 20, 2020.
public-advisory.Description: The Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development is in the process of providing much needed road work and rehabilitation on the Morton Lake Forest Road accessing Morton Lake Park. Due to heavy equipment on site through this period the road is closed to all traffic.

public-advisory.Title: Visitor Centre closed and cave tours suspended
public-advisory.Description:
Due to precautions against the spread of the COVID-19 virus, and to ensure the health and safety of parks visitors, volunteers and all employees, the visitor centre has been closed and all cave tours have been suspended until further notice.

The public is also advised that the two self-guiding caves, are also closed to the public until further notice.

All trails remain open along with outdoor pit toilet facilities. Maintenance and monitoring of park will continue. We are encouraging people to follow the recommendations of the Provincial Health Officer and the BC Centre for Disease Control. Please monitor the this page for further notices. Thank you for your understanding and cooperation.

public-advisory.Title: Off-Road Vehicles prohibited in park
public-advisory.Description: Off-Road Vehicles (ORVs) are prohibited in this park. ORVs include ATVs, off-road motorcycles, snowmobiles and side-by-sides.

public-advisory.Title: Bobtail Mountain access road conditions - removed bridge
public-advisory.Description:
Gregg Creek Forest Service Road is rough with potholes and logging activity; please use caution when traveling the road. Bobtail Mountain Road is in fair condition from the turn off from the Gregg Creek Forest Service Road at 23.5 km to 5 km where the bridge has been removed.

Please note that the removal of the bridge will add 2km to your hike each way. Please park appropriately at this location to allow other users access to the area. Use caution when crossing the creek.

public-advisory.Title: Trail condition in poor shape - Travel not recommended
public-advisory.Description: Please be advised the trail up to the Holliday Creek Arch is in very bad shape with windfall, washouts and several areas where detours are required. Travel is not recommended unless you are prepared for these conditions.

public-advisory.Title: The gate to the upper summer parking lot has now been locked and is closed for the winter season
public-advisory.Description: As the access road leading up to the park is not maintained being prepared and equipped with 4x4, good winter chains, shovel and tow ropes at a minimum is strongly recommended. Whenever possible, please spread vehicle tracks across the road to avoid creating deep ruts. Enjoy the snow.

public-advisory.Description:

  • Check the avalanche conditions at avalanche.ca.

public-advisory.Description: There is no vehicle access into the park.

public-advisory.Title: Empress Bypass trail closed
public-advisory.Description: Empress Bypass trail will be closed for trail maintenance until Thursday, Nov 19. Thank you for your patience.

public-advisory.Title: Gates closed due to snow
Park gates are now closed for the season
public-advisory.Description: Parking in front of the gates or along highway 99 is prohibited and vehicles will be towed at owners expense.

public-advisory.Title: Due to extreme rain events and potential for highwater and flooding on the Atnarko River the Belarko Boat Launch and Fisheries Pool Campground are closed for public safety until further notice
Snowmobile use no longer permitted in any area of Elk Lakes Park
public-advisory.Description: The previous special exemption to use snowmobiles to access Abruzzi Lake along the seismic corridor is no longer in effect. The entire park is closed to all motorized activities. Non-compliance of the motorized closure will result in enforcement actions.

public-advisory.Title: The RCMP has closed the Chief Backside/Chief Peaks Trail and parking lot
public-advisory.Description: This notice will be removed when the area is re-opened.

public-advisory.Title: Park will be closed from Oct. 28 – Nov. 4 for construction
public-advisory.Description: No public access will be available during this time. Sorry for any inconvenience.

public-advisory.Title: Due to extreme rain events and hazard for potential flooding the Tote Road is closed until further notice.
BC Hydro scheduled power outage Tuesday, November 17, 2020
public-advisory.Description: Two 2-hour outages from 8:00 AM – 10:00 AM and from 6:00 PM – 8:00 PM on Tuesday, November 17, 2020 due to BC Hydro work in the area.

public-advisory.Title: Water facilities closed due to cold weather
public-advisory.Description:
Due to overnight freezing temperatures, above ground and external water sources such as the drinking fountains, water taps and the sani-station will be shut down as of Friday, October 23, 2020 and will remain off until temperatures rise.

Water is accessible in the washroom buildings; however, access is limited so we ask that campers plan ahead and bring a larger supply of potable water.

public-advisory.Title: Botanical Beach Temporarily Closed
public-advisory.Description:
Due to a problem bear in the area, Botanical Beach remains closed for public safety. BC Parks is closely monitoring and assessing the activity and behaviour of the bear. The closure is reassessed daily and Botanical Beach will be open as soon as possible. This message will be removed when the area has re-opened.

To access the Juan de Fuca Trail at the west end, please use the Parkinson Creek Trailhead.

public-advisory.Title: Main gate closed due to snow fall
public-advisory.Description: Weather conditions will continue to be monitored and the gate will be reopened when snow levels decrease.

public-advisory.Title: Campground not available
public-advisory.Description: Due to the extremely cold temperatures forecasted for this weekend water at Kekuli bay campground will not be available as of October 23, 2020

public-advisory.Title: Bridge removal project complete
public-advisory.Description: Bridge removal on multi-use trail near Mt. Sullivan is now complete. The trail will remain closed until the end of November when the new pedestrian crossing will be in place. Please note that the park boundary is approximately 200m east of the crossing near the CRD Waste Water Treatment plant.

public-advisory.Title: Boat launch closed to public
public-advisory.Description:
Lac Le Jeune boat launch is closed to public use due to construction activities.

Duration closed: Monday, October 26 – Friday, October 30, 2020

Well drilling equipment will be working near the boat launch and pumphouse blocking off access during this time period. This closure is only temporary while drilling activities take place. Thank you for you patience while we endeavour to improve our service facilities at the Park.

public-advisory.Title: Water facilities closed due to cold weather
public-advisory.Description: Due to overnight freezing temperatures, above ground and external water sources such as the drinking fountains, water taps and the sani-station will be shut down as of Friday, Oct. 23 and will remain off until temperatures rise. Water is accessible in the washroom buildings, however access is limited, so we ask that campers plan ahead and bring a larger supply of potable water.

public-advisory.Title: Anhluut’ukwsim Laxmihl Angwinga’asanskwhl Nisga’a (a.k.a. Nisga’a Memorial Lava Bed Park) re-opened with exceptions
public-advisory.Description:
All visitors must be self-sufficient as all services in Nisga’a villages will remain closed to the public.

The BC Parks campground and specific facilities will be available for public use. Some facilities and locations will remain closed due to their proximity to the communities or because they have been identified as places where COVID-19 risk mitigation strategies cannot be maintained.

  • The Visitor Center will not be open
  • The boat launch will not be available for public use until further notice
  • The Tseax auto tour stop and parking lots (by Gitlaxt’aamiks) will remain closed until further notice (due to proximity to communities)
  • Lava Lake auto stop will remain closed until further notice
  • The suspension bridge and fish wheel auto tour stop (by Gitwinksihlkw) will remain closed until further notice
  • The campground and visitor center parking lot is currently open for day-use only
  • All other day use area and auto tour stops are open

This decision was jointly made by BC Parks and the Nisga’a Lisims Government. The situation will be monitored to ensure the continued health and safety of members of the Nisga’a community, BC Parks employees, park operators, and visitors. Ministry staff, along with NLG’s Department of Compliance and Enforcement, will be actively patrolling the park to ensure compliance with the specific site closures.

public-advisory.Title: Parking lot closed for the remainder of the 2020 season
public-advisory.Description:
Due to recent theft and vandalism events that have occurred in the park, the parking lot will be closed for the remainder of the 2020 season.

The park remains open and can still be accessed on foot.

public-advisory.Title: Notice of temporary trail closure
public-advisory.Description:
The Morden Colliery Regional Trail and all of Morden Colliery Historic Provincial Park will be closed for five days while BC Parks removes the containers used to stabilize the tipple structure, situated beside the parking lot serving the Provincial Park and Regional Trail.

When: Monday, November 16 – Friday, November 20, 2020
7 am to 7 pm

public-advisory.Title: Blackwall Road and Lone Duck 1 Shelter winter closures
public-advisory.Description:
Blackwall Road to the Cascade Lookout and Alpine Meadows is now closed for the season to vehicle traffic due to snow.

Lone Duck 1 shared winter shelter will not be open this year due to COVID-19.

public-advisory.Title: Campground and park gate closed for the winter
public-advisory.Description:
Rolley Lake Campground and park main gate are closed for the winter. No vehicle access to park, but foot traffic is welcome. Overnight camping is not permitted. Winter camping is available nearby at Golden Ears Provincial Park.

Rolley Lake Campground and main gate will reopen on April 1, 2021.
See dates of operation.

public-advisory.Title: Golden Ears Provincial Park winter hours
public-advisory.Description:
Golden Ears Provincial Park is now operating on winter hours. The park gate is open 8am - 5:30pm daily, please exit the park by 5:30pm. If hazardous road conditions exist (snow/ice on road), the park gate will remain closed all day. Winter camping is available at Gold Creek Campground when the park road is open.
See dates of operation. For updates on road conditions and closures, visit the Park Operator’s Twitter feed @alouetteparks

public-advisory.Title: Tote Road and Stillwater Lake Trail Conditions Update
public-advisory.Description:
Due to 2017 wildfire activity, significant flood risk hazard and debris flow hazard exists at drainages along the Tote Rd. Park visitors should avoid travelling on the Tote Rd during high water or rain events.

Due to rockfall on the Tote Road, it is driveable only by 4x4 high clearance vehicles with narrow wheelbase.

Stillwater lake trail is open.
public-advisory.Note: Cancelled so Rob can use this request to show Steven how to do advisories

public-advisory.Title: Temporary noise and trail closures
public-advisory.Description: Park visitors may expect some minor noise disturbance and traffic flow delays as a fuel management treatment project is being carried out. For the safety of the public, some trails may also be temporarily closed while this activity is taking place.

public-advisory.Title: Expect winter snow conditions all across Garibaldi Park
Cheakamus campground flooding
public-advisory.Description: Cheakamus campground is currently experiencing flooding due to heavy rain. Two of the eight campsites are covered in water.

public-advisory.Title: Traffic pattern change at Manson’s Landing Oct. 16, 2020
public-advisory.Description:
In order to protect the sensitive coastal sands ecosystems at Manson’s Landing Park, the rock barriers that prevent vehicle access to the spit will be relocated. The barriers will be moved approximately, 80m South toward the boat launch turn around area . Please use the boat launch with care. Assist restoration efforts by parking vehicles and trailers in the parking area opposite the government dock, once you have finished launching your boat.

The rock barriers will be relocated on October 16, 2020. Please note, boat launch access will be limited while the work is being completed. Thank-you for your cooperation.

public-advisory.Title: Day-use passes are not required to visit the park at this time
Picnic Shelter remains closed for the season
Tote Road and Stillwater Lake Trail Conditions Update
public-advisory.Description:
2.5 km in from the entrance to the Tote Road a rockslide has occurred blocking off the Tote road to all forms of traffic including ATVs.

Due to 2017 wildfire activity, significant flood risk hazard and debris flow hazard exists at drainages along the Tote Rd. Park visitors should avoid travelling on the Tote Rd during high water or rain events.

Due to rockfall on the Tote Road, it is driveable only by 4x4 high clearance vehicles with narrow wheelbase.

Stillwater lake trail is open.

public-advisory.Title: Osprey Campground/Group Use and Day Use area closed until Oct. 31
public-advisory.Description: The Osprey Campground/Group Use and Day Use area is closed until Oct. 31 and will be inaccessible for vehicle traffic. Day users can access the park via the boat launch road, with vehicle parking and turn around at the boat launch parking area. After Oct. 31, park access will again be available via the Osprey parking area.

public-advisory.Title: Goldstream day-use area is without water until further notice
public-advisory.Description: Portable toilets with hand-sanitizer will be provided.

public-advisory.Title: Road closure at Goldstream Campground
public-advisory.Description: Road Closure for hydro tree work at Goldstream Campground from Oct. 6-8 (10:00am – 2:00 pm). Golden Gate Road will be closed and there will be no vehicle or pedestrian access (in or out) during this time.

public-advisory.Title: Bowron Lake Canoe Circuit reservations opening 2021
public-advisory.Description: Due to uncertainty regarding the ongoing pandemic, reservations for the Bowron Lake Canoe Circuit will now open January 2021 instead of October 2020.
public-advisory.Note: Changed October 1, 2020 to October 2020 on Dec. 16, 2020

public-advisory.Title: Berg Lake Trail reservations opening 2021
public-advisory.Description: Due to uncertainty regarding the ongoing pandemic, reservations for the Berg Lake Trail will now open January 2021 instead of October 2020.
public-advisory.Note: Changed October 1, 2020 to October 2020 on Dec. 16, 2020

public-advisory.Title: Akamina Parkway opening
public-advisory.Description: Akamina Parkway in Waterton Lakes National Park is now open as of Monday, Sept. 21 to Sept. 30 for non-motorized use (hiking and biking). Starting Thursday, Oct. 1 the parkway will be open for motorized use.

public-advisory.Title: Construction is underway for the Trans Mountain Expansion Project - please obey all posted signs and closures
Park will be closed as of October 12, 2020, and there will be no public access to boat launch and parking area until further notice
public-advisory.Description: In order to complete improvements to the boat launch and parking area at Shuswap Lake Provincial Park, all public access to this location is prohibited. Tree falling, trucking, excavators, rock work, facility removal, brush and pit run transport to and from the pit, and possibly some boat launch slab replacement will make the area unsafe for public use. Your cooperation is greatly appreciated while we complete these facility upgrades.

public-advisory.Title: Access to the boat launch may be closed for short periods of time
public-advisory.Description: Due to park water system upgrades, access to the boat launch may be closed for short periods of time. In addition, traffic control will be in effect along Broadwater Road between the boat launch and campground. This work will commence on October 1, 2020.

public-advisory.Title: A cougar has been observed near the Timberman Trail
public-advisory.Description: Be cougar smart and keep your pets on leash.

public-advisory.Title: Vehicle use in Chemainus River Park is restricted to Hillcrest Road (Forest Service Road)
public-advisory.Description: Driving on park trails disrupts and damages natural areas. Operators of vehicles found off-road may be fined under the Park, Conservancy and Recreation Area Regulation (minimum $575, maximum $200,000).

public-advisory.Title: Off-road vehicle registration is mandatory
public-advisory.Description: Starting in 2015, off-road vehicle registration is mandatory on crown land, including on forest service roads. Find out more at: Off-Road Vehicle Management Framework.

public-advisory.Title: No camping or campfires are permitted in this park at any time
Moul Falls parking lot closed until further notice
public-advisory.Description: The parking area at the Moul Falls trailhead is closed until further notice, while BC Recreation Sites and Trails conducts upgrades and expands the parking opportunities in this area.

public-advisory.Title: Cougar in area
public-advisory.Description: A cougar has been observed in the campground area. For visitor safety, some camping sites and trails have been closed. For yours and the cougar’s safety, please respect closed areas and keep pets on leash.

public-advisory.Title: Park gate closed 10:45am–2:15pm on Tuesday, Sept. 22
public-advisory.Description:
On Tuesday, September 22, 2020, work on the front entrance of the park will be occurring from 10:45am–2:15pm. Access to the park will be restricted during this time. Please see attached document for further details. We appreciate your patience.

  • Mabel Lake Gate Closure Sept. 22

public-advisory.Title: Picnic shelter closed until further notice
Full park closure will be in effect as of October 1, 2020
Sea to Summit Trail closed until further notice. Thank you for your understanding
public-advisory.Description: The Backside trail has been cleared by the RCMP, but Sea to Summit will not be opened for the foreseeable future.

public-advisory.Title: Halloween event postponed
public-advisory.Description: This year’s Halloween event, scheduled for the Thanksgiving weekend, will be postponed until next year.  We are taking every precaution regarding COVID 19 and given the clear guidelines of safe social distancing, we are not in a position to safely operate the event this year.  While we understand this will be disappointing to many, we thank you in advance for your understanding and patience. We look forward to the event being scheduled next year!

public-advisory.Title: Boat launch closed until further notice
public-advisory.Description: Due to low water levels and the potential for visitors to damage their vehicles and equipment the public boat Launch at Shuswap Lake Provincial Park is closed until further notice.  Please monitor this webpage for future updates.

public-advisory.Title: Active bear in area
public-advisory.Description: An adult black bear is active throughout the park, including the Backside Trail, Campground and climbing areas. Please be bear aware and secure all attractants in your vehicle when in the park If you encounter the bear, please report it to the RAPP line: 1-877-952-7277

public-advisory.Title: Sea to Summit Trail and Backside Trail closed until further notice. Thank you for your understanding
public-advisory.Note: removed ’ and Backside Trail ’ on Sept. 16

public-advisory.Title: Bear Advisory – updated September 14, 2020 and ongoing
public-advisory.Description:
BC Parks has received ongoing reports of bear observations in San Josef Bay Area and along the North Coast Trail. All visitors and hikers in Cape Scott must be extremely mindful about how they recreate in bear habitat to help prevent bears from becoming habituated to humans and conditioned to insecure attractants.

Please do your part when recreating in bear country and help keep bears wild.

  • More about wildlife safety
  • More about backcountry etiquette

If you encounter an aggressive wild animal, report it by calling the Conservation Officer Service 24-hour hotline toll free at 1-877-952-7277 (RAPP) or #7277 on the Telus Mobility Network.

public-advisory.Title: Park will be closed for the season as of October 1, 2020
public-advisory.Description: The gates will be locked and the park closed to the public as of October 1st, 2020 for the remainder of the season.  BC Parks in collaboration with Neskonlith Lake Indian Band and the Thompson Rivers District, will be conducting a Wildfire Risk Reduction Fuel Management project to protect park values, enhance visitor safety, and contribute to landscape-level wildfire risk reduction initiatives. The project will be starting October 1st, 2020 and will be completed prior to March 1st, 2021.

public-advisory.Title: Log jam on Gitnadoiks River
public-advisory.Description: There is a log jam on the Gitnadoiks River, 500 meters upstream from the PNG line that impedes travel. The log jam is at a bend in the river where turning around is difficult. We do not recommend travelling up the Gitnadoiks River at this time.

public-advisory.Title: Gruchy’s Beach closed September 21st, 2020 to November 30th, 2020
public-advisory.Description: Work will commence to build a new turning lane into Gruchy’s beach day-use site in Lakelse Lake Provincial Park on September 15th, 2020. This work is required to improve the safety of park visitors and the public travelling to Gruchys Beach and along Highway 37 South. In order to ensure the safety of the contractor, staff, and public, the Gruchys Beach day-use area will be completely closed to the public as of September 21st, 2020. We appreciate your understanding, cooperation, and patience while work is underway.
public-advisory.Note: set to partial closure for this time period

public-advisory.Title: Park re-opening details
public-advisory.Description:
Picnic area open for day-use as of May 14, 2020 – Picnic shelter remains closed, no water or flush toilets available, not all services will be available.

Furlong Bay open for camping and day-use as of June 1, 2020 – Picnic shelter and amphitheatre remain closed.

public-advisory.Title: The 2020 camping season has been extended at this park - see Dates of Operation table below
We appreciate your feeback!
public-advisory.Description: If you have visited Big Creek Provincial Park, we would appreciate if you could please complete an online comment form. This will allow park managers to obtain valuable information from those who have experienced the area. This form is not for providing input to the management planning process.

public-advisory.Title: Bear sightings in Bedwell Lakes area
public-advisory.Description:
Black bears has been frequenting the Bedwell Lakes area. Visitors are reminded to be extra cautious in the area. If camping, ensure all food and scented items are carefully stored in the provided food caches and keep the campsite clean.
  • How to stay safe in bear country
Report any further sightings to the Park Operator or through RAPP Line 1-877-952-7277 (Cell: #7277)

public-advisory.Title: Caution: Due to historic military training exercises in the Cosens Bay area, Unexploded Ordinance (UXOs) may be present
public-advisory.Description: Please stay on designated trails at all times. If a UXO is encountered, do not touch it and call 911.

public-advisory.Title: Campground capacity
public-advisory.Description: Walk-in camping is not permitted if the gate is locked. Bench campground is closed and will only open if overflow sites are required in the event that Hicks Lake and Lakeside campgrounds are full.

public-advisory.Title: Delta Grove Campground, Maple Bay Campground, and Maple Bay Cabins are available for reservation
public-advisory.Description: There are no first-come, first-served sites available in the park. Clear Creak Campground and Entrance Bay Campground are closed.

public-advisory.Title: The Nels Bight and Cape Sutil Ranger Station Cabins will be closed to public access until further notice
public-advisory.Description: Campers must be self-sufficient and prepared to camp at all locations within the park. Thank you for your cooperation.

public-advisory.Title: Due to demand, as of 2017, all sites in McDonald Creek Campground are reservable from June 21 – September 12, 2020
public-advisory.Description: During this period, non-occupied reservation sites can accommodate first-come, first-served customers for one, or perhaps more nights, depending on availability.

public-advisory.Title: Beginning September 8th, Radium is available on a first-come, first-served basis and Paleface is available by reservation only
public-advisory.Description: Flora, Lindeman and Greendrop loops are closed.

public-advisory.Title: Monashee and Trinity Campgrounds
public-advisory.Description: Reservations for the Trinity loop have been extended through October 12, 2020. The Monashee loop will continue as first-come, first-served until the end of the 2020 camping season.

public-advisory.Title: Surveyor’s Lake Campground closed on September 15 for the remainder of the season
public-advisory.Description:
BC Parks will be closing Surveyor’s Lake Campground on September 15, 2020 for the remainder of the season, in order to complete facility upgrades. The project will include resurfacing each campsite and replacing the picnic tables, fire rings and number posts. Park visitors should be aware that heavy equipment will be transitioning through the park and working in Surveyor’s Lake Campground.

Camping opportunities will continue to be available in Kalispell and Ponderosa Campgrounds until September 30, 2020.

public-advisory.Title: Road Closures
public-advisory.Description: The Clearwater River Road (the gravel road along the west side of the Clearwater River, used primarily by fishers and kayakers) is closed beyond the Kettle at 9km, due to water damage. Updates will be provided as conditions change but the road may be inaccessible beyond the Kettle for some time.
public-advisory.Note: Removed this on Dec. 3: Battle Mountain Road is now open to the first parking lot at 2.5 km, but closed to vehicle traffic after that. Note that the road surface is still rough and a high-clearance, 4x4 vehicle is recommended.

public-advisory.Title: Gwe Da Ts’ih Campground closing September 15
public-advisory.Description: Gwe Da Ts’ih Campground will be closed as of September 15th 2020, to prevent human-bear interactions this fall.

public-advisory.Title: Kennedy Lake Park is a day-use park
public-advisory.Description:
Camping and overnight parking is strictly prohibited.

Anyone found in the park between 11pm and 7am will be evicted and will receive violation tickets.

public-advisory.Title: Illegally parked vehicles
public-advisory.Description:
Starting September 5, 2020, vehicles parked illegally at Porteau Cove Park will be subject to towing at the owner’s expense. Visitors must park in designated parking lots and observe the “no parking” signs posted.

Illegal parking has become a safety issue at Porteau Cove Park, with vehicles blocking access for emergency response and people parking along the highway. Thank you for making a visit to Porteau Cove safe for everyone.

public-advisory.Title: Buckhorn campground closed beginning September 8, 2020
public-advisory.Description: Buckhorn campground will be closed on September 8th for the remainder of the season to upgrade and expand facilities for the 2021 camping season. The Heather trail will remain open during this time, however hikers may be asked to briefly stop while traveling through the area of Buckhorn camp. The upper parking area at the sub-alpine meadows will be closed from September 8th-11th to allow for storage of materials for this project.

public-advisory.Title: Boil water advisory
public-advisory.Description: Visitors are advised to boil water retrieved from handpumps at Nairn Falls for at least one minute before drinking.

public-advisory.Title: Findlay and Dutch Creek trailheads closed due to wildfire
public-advisory.Description:
Access to the Findlay and Dutch Creek trailheads is currently closed due to the Doctor Creek Wildfire.
  • Map of the affected area (BC Wildfire Service website)

public-advisory.Title: No parking on Alice Lake Road
public-advisory.Description: In order to maintain park safety and public security, all vehicles parked illegally and on road edges will be subject to towing at the owner’s expense.

public-advisory.Title: Running water unavailable at Shelter Bay Site
public-advisory.Description: Due to a waterline break, the Shelter Bay Site is currently without running water. Updates will be posted when available.

public-advisory.Title: Cowichan Valley Trail (Trans Canada Trail) closed
public-advisory.Description:
The Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure has closed the Cowichan Valley Trail between Holt Creek Trestle and 66 Mile Trestle. Repairs to the trestles and trail washouts are anticipated to complete in mid-October 2020. Please note during this time, the Cowichan River Footpath in the area of the repairs may be impacted/closed for the work.
  • Information Bulletin

public-advisory.Title: Trail and recreational access closures this fall
public-advisory.Description:
Trail and recreational access closures this fall

Please be advised that BC Parks will be conducting three fuel management projects in West Arm Park this fall (September to December). To ensure public safety during these treatments, there will be trail closures and recreational access closures associated with all three projects.

  1. 12.7 hectare hand treatment 1km up Svoboda Road in the vicinity of Short Svoboda, Frog Jam, Squeeler, and Toe Jam Trails. Expect trail closures from September 8th until late November or early December. Please also see trail information on the Nelson Cycling Club’s Facebook page.
  2. 12.7 hectare hand treatment along Lasca Road. There will be no recreational access beyond the gate as of September 1st until late November or early December.
  3. 15.4 hectare mechanical treatment at the end of Lasca Road. There will be no recreational access beyond the gate as of September 1st until late November or early December.

Please obey all informational signage posted on site and please check this website often for the latest updates.

For more information please call 250 489-9211.

public-advisory.Title: Recreation trails between the campgrounds are closed
public-advisory.Description: A slump in the silt bluff between the campgrounds at Okanagan Lake Park have closed the recreation trails between them. It is likely that the trails will remain closed at minimum for the remainder of 2020.

public-advisory.Title: Porcupine Advisory
public-advisory.Description: If leaving your vehicle at the trail head, we suggest that you surround your vehicle with chicken wire. Porcupines may chew on brake and fuel lines.

public-advisory.Title: Little Slocan FSR south end closed due to wildfire
public-advisory.Description: Due to wildfires, the Little Slocan FSR is closed from the Passmore (south) end. Drinnon Pass/Gwillim Lakes (Hoder Crerek FSR) and Mt. Gimli/Mulvey Basin (Bannock Burn FSR) are still accessible from the north end at Slocan.

public-advisory.Title: Park closed beginning in September for facility upgrades
public-advisory.Description: BC Parks will be closing Bijoux falls for September and possibly October for upgrades to the Faculties. Please plan your trip accordingly as public access will not be allowed to the Falls during this time. Thank you for your cooperation.

public-advisory.Title: Goldstream day-use area is without water until further notice
public-advisory.Description: Portable toilets with hand-sanitizer will be provided.

public-advisory.Title: The main parking lot at Spider Lake is temporarily closed to protect the migrating Western Toads
public-advisory.Description: Please utilize the smaller parking lot closer to Highway 19 until the main parking lot can be reopened. Please do not park in front of the gate or otherwise obstruct traffic along the public road. If parking is not available, please consider visiting another park in the region during this temporary parking lot closure. When visiting the park, please watch your step, as the tiny toads can easily blend in with their surroundings.

public-advisory.Title: No firewood available to purchase in the park
Seasonal park closures to mitigate risk of human-bear conflict
public-advisory.Description: The Pinkut Site of Babine Lake Marine Provincial Park, adjacent to the Department of Fisheries and Oceans’ Pinkut Creek Spawning Channels on Babine Lake, will be closed annually from September 1st to December 31st. This is being implemented by BC Parks in order to mitigate the risk of human-bear conflict during the salmon spawning season, when grizzly bears are more active in the area. Any questions or concerns can be directed to BC Parks at 250 847-7426.

public-advisory.Title: Hind Hut Closure
public-advisory.Description: The Hind Hut is currently closed due to COVID-19. Hikers and climbers will need to plan and prepare accordingly. Camping is available by reservation only within the core area of the park. Please visit BC Parks reservation site at: discovercamping.ca for more information.

public-advisory.Title: Sombrio Beach access trail maintenance
public-advisory.Description: Please be advised routine maintenance will be taking place on the Sombrio Beach access trail. Please be aware of crew and equipment, and follow safety signage.

public-advisory.Title: Hamill Creek Trail closed at 3<sup>rd</sup> cable car crossing
public-advisory.Description: Hamill Creek Trail closed at 3<sup>rd</sup> cable car crossing due to hazard trees within the area.

public-advisory.Title: Boiling water advisory at Hicks Lake
public-advisory.Description: Visitors are advised to boil water for at least two minute before drinking.
public-advisory.Note: Adjusted the description: Visitors are advised to boil water retrieved from handpumps at Hicks Lake for at least one minute before drinking.

public-advisory.Title: Washroom buildings at Honeymoon Bay group campsite are unavailable until further notice
public-advisory.Description: Thank you for your patience.

public-advisory.Title: The Castle Pass Trail is currently closed due to a potentially aggressive grizzly bear
public-advisory.Description: BC Parks is assessing the situation at this time and will reopen once it is safe to do so.

public-advisory.Title: The Castle Pass Trail is currently closed due to a potentially aggressive grizzly bear
public-advisory.Description: BC Parks is assessing the situation at this time and will reopen once it is safe to do so.

public-advisory.Title: Falls Lake Trail Improvements
public-advisory.Description: Trail improvements will be occurring on the Falls Lake Trail on August 20–22, 2020, including replacing a series of foot bridges. Travel on the trail may be limited and delays are to be expected. The Falls Lake campground will be occupied by the trail crew and will have limited or no availability for public overnight use.

public-advisory.Title: The Washout Creek and Fortress Creek Campgrounds have been decommissioned due to dangerous trees
public-advisory.Description: Please use at your own risk.

public-advisory.Title: Fording the Athabasca River is not recommended
public-advisory.Description: There is no estimated time for repair or replacement of this bridge.

public-advisory.Title: Phase 3 of the restoration project has begun
public-advisory.Description: Restoration (Phase 3) of the historic concrete tipple has started. Due to the movement of machinery, please exercise caution when accessing the park and obey all signage.

public-advisory.Title: Monkman Memorial Trail bridge upgrades in August
public-advisory.Description:
The Monkman Memorial Trail will be receiving bridge upgrades between August 18th to August 31st between the trail head and Monkman Lake. Please be aware of helicopters working August 18th and work crews that will be working along the trail.

The Monkman Memorial Trail will be closed at the suspension bridge from August 25th to August 29th. Please follow the direction of park rangers and work crews in the area. Thank you for your assistance.

public-advisory.Title: Maximum 8 people per campsite at all times
public-advisory.Description: This includes all campers and visitors.

public-advisory.Title: New campsites and accessibility improvements at Loveland Bay Provincial Park
public-advisory.Description:
In response to public demand for increased camping opportunities in highly desirable locations, the Provincial Government has invested $22.9 million in campgrounds throughout British Columbia over the last five years.

This includes new campsites at Loveland Bay Provincial Park. Over the next year, 22 additional campsites will be added to meet increased demand. This project will also include upgrades to the existing campsites, a reconstructed beach area, new toilet facilities, expanded parking and improved accessibility to visitors. In addition, improvements to the campground road will result in better passage for fish and amphibians.

  • Loveland Bay Campground Expansion Sign [PDF]

public-advisory.Title: To protect both people and bears, special regulations in place during the salmon run
public-advisory.Description:
BC Parks is eagerly anticipating the return of the Kokanee salmon to the spawning channel at Kokanee Creek Park. The park has an elevated boardwalk to allow visitors to view the salmon in the spawning channel. BC Parks would like to remind visitors that during the spawning period, bears are also frequent visitors to the channel to feed on the salmon. To protect both people and bears, the spawning channel viewing areas have special regulations in place during the salmon run.

These restrictions will come into effect when the Kokanee spawning is occurring in the channel, from August 14th to October 7th, 2020 and will include:

  1. Dogs will not be permitted on the boardwalk or the trails adjacent to the spawning channel.
  2. Bicycles must be walked across the boardwalk and along the trails adjacent to the spawning channel.
  3. The portion of the spawning channel downstream of the viewing platform will be closed to the public during the period that bears are utilizing it for feeding. This closure will include the trails behind the Nature Center.
  4. Please respect the new covid-19 guidelines and traffic flow signs for the Spawning Channel trails. Wearing a mask is encouraged.

White-Nose Syndrome
public-advisory.Description:
White-nose Syndrome is a fungal disease that has been linked to the mass die-off of hibernating bats in Eastern North America – it poses a significant threat to bats of the west and British Columbia. There is evidence that humans have accelerated the spread through entering caves with contaminated clothing, gear or equipment. To help prevent WNS from taking hold in B.C., the Province is making investments in bat conservation projects.

To ensure the protection of bats and their habitat in this park, BC Parks strongly advises that personal caving gear that has been used anywhere east of the Rockies not be used in B.C. Also, before entering caves in B.C, cavers and visitors should consult the provincial WNS website, which includes a link to a Decontamination Protocol for Mines and Caves.

  • Learn more about white-nose syndrome

While travelling on the Walker Creek Forest Service Road (FSR), attention is required to navigate the surface as it is uneven, rutted, slippery and very rough. The road is not recommended for anything other than a 4x4, high clearance vehicle, and drivers familiar with this type of vehicle operation.

The trail between Bastille Creek and Buchanan Creek can result in quite a bit of hiking around sections where the old road surface has washed away and some travel on muddy sections of the winter snowmobile route due to ATV/UTV traffic and wet conditions up to Buchanan Creek where ATV/UTV traffic is not permitted within the boundaries of the Park. Visitors planning to camp overnight are asked to limit the length of their stay, and advised to make back-up plans since the campground is likely to be full.

public-advisory.Title: Bridge removal project
public-advisory.Description: On August 17, 2020, BC Parks will be closing one section of a multi-use trail near Mt. Sullivan for a stream restoration project involving the removal of an old log bridge crossing and stabilization of the stream channel and banks. This work will address the issue of bridge material slumping into the salmon bearing creek below, negatively affecting fish habitat, clogging culverts in the lower reaches of the creek and eroding archeological sites. The trail will remain closed while BC Parks monitors the bank stabilization and determines an appropriate form and location of a new crossing. Additional stream diversion work will also be taking place upland and below the bridge site to help restore natural flows and address trail erosion issues. Minor disruptions can be expected.

public-advisory.Title: Drinking water at Mahood Lake campground on permanent boil water order
public-advisory.Description:
Park Visitors are advised to either bring their own potable water or boil water prior to consumption. Interior Health advises the following:
  • Boiling water is the most effective way to disinfect water, particularly if you think your water has parasites such as Giardia or Cryptosporidium, or if you have a weakened immune system.
  • Boil water for at least 1 minute. At elevations over 2,000 meters (6,500 feet) boil water for at least 2 minutes.
  • Store disinfected water in clean, covered, food grade containers
BC Parks is working with Interior Health and our Capital program and hopes to develop a new drinking water source at the Park in the near future. Unfortunately this will take some time. Please consult this web page for future updates.
