public-advisory.Title: Park Opening Announcement
public-advisory.Description:
BC Parks is very pleased to announce jointly with Xeni Gwet’in First Nation that Ts’il?os Provincial Park is open for both day-use and overnight camping, including Nu Chugh Beniz & Gwe Da Ts’ih campgrounds.

BC Parks has continued to keep the health and wellbeing of our visitors, staff, park operators, and local communities as our top priority by implementing COVID-19 safety protocols and respecting continued PHO guidelines around physical distancing,

The BC Parks Guide to Camping During COVID-19 is an excellent resource to help you understand what to expect when you arrive at the campgrounds. The guide outlines how to prepare, set up, and stay safe while visiting BC Parks.

All visitors to Ts’il?os Park are asked to be fully self-contained and to have no contact with local community members in the Nemiah Valley in order to limit the chance of spreading the COVID-19 virus. The gas station, tire repair and convenience store are closed to non-residents. Visitors are reminded to check www.xenigwetin.net for updates on access to Title Lands.

We appreciate your ongoing cooperation as we work to keep our staff, park operators, local communities, and visitors safe.

Extreme caution, especially with children or pets, should be exercised at this time. In some locations the river is flowing at less than a metre from the backside of campsites. Both the North and the South Thompson Rivers have peaked and extreme flows should start to subside in the next week.

These roads at the present time are only maintained to an industrial standard and will be very rough in some areas.

public-advisory.Title: You are in bear country
public-advisory.Description:
• Coolers are not bear proof
  • Secure all food and attractants; unsecured attractants may result in eviction and/or fines
  • Dispose of garbage and grey water in approved receptacles
  • Never approach or feed a bear
  • Report all bear sightings

public-advisory.Title: BC Parks warns visitors to use extra caution due to high water in the Thompson River
public-advisory.Description: With all the campsites in this popular park being located along the Thompson River, and the extreme high water flows currently being experienced, BC Parks is warning our visitors to use extra caution. Extreme caution, especially with children or pets, should be exercised at this time. In some locations the river is flowing at less than a metre from the backside of campsites. Both the North and the South Thompson Rivers have peaked and extreme flows should start to subside in the next week.

public-advisory.Title: Tour buses prohibited
public-advisory.Description: Tour Buses are prohibited in this park due to COVID-19 response.

public-advisory.Title: Reduced Parking
public-advisory.Description: Please note that parking has been reduced by 50% to maintain physical distancing due to COVID-19 response; plan to arrive early or on weekdays to ensure a parking spot.

public-advisory.Title: The Inland Lake trail may not be currently passable with all types of wheelchairs/scooters
public-advisory.Description: Trail work will be occurring and BC Parks will update this webpage once the work is completed. We appreciate your patience.

public-advisory.Title: Campsite Construction
public-advisory.Description: A new campground loop is currently being constructed Monday - Friday until October 1st. Campsites 1-8 will be the most impacted from noise generated from the construction.

public-advisory.Title: First loop of Hampton Campground opening July 9
public-advisory.Description: As of July 9th, the first loop of Hampton Campground (sites 1-24 and 79-100) will be open, including the playground and toilet shower building. Amenities in the remaining areas of the campground continue to be closed until further notice.

public-advisory.Title: Closures Due To Flooding
public-advisory.Description: Due to heavy rainfall and local flooding, the day-use area (including the boat launch) and portions of the campground will be closed until conditions improve. Please continue to visit the website for further updates.

public-advisory.Title: Road Closures
public-advisory.Description:
The Clearwater River Road (the gravel road along the west side of the Clearwater River, used primarily by fishers and kayakers) is closed beyond the Kettle at 9km, due to water damage. Updates will be provided as conditions change but the road may be inaccessible beyond the Kettle for some time.

The Battle Mountain Road is also closed at this time due to water damage.

public-advisory.Title: Clearwater Valley Road and Clearwater River Road Closures
public-advisory.Description: The Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure has closed the Clearwater Valley Road, also known as the Park Road, just north of Spahats Falls due to water damage.  The road remains open to residents, but public access remains open only to Spahats Falls and the Trophy Mountains. The Clearwater River Road (the gravel road along the west side of the Clearwater River, used primarily by fishers and kayakers) is closed beyond the Kettle at 9km, again due to water damage. Updates will be provided as conditions change.

public-advisory.Title: Muddy conditions on Bugaboo Forest Service Road
public-advisory.Description: Muddy conditions on Bugaboo Forest Service Road are preventing 2 wheel drive access to the Bugaboo trailhead. Low clearance vehicles not recommended for access to the park.

public-advisory.Title: Blackwall Road, to the sub-alpine meadows, and the Heather trail will open on Friday, July 3rd
public-advisory.Description: Please note, the upper parking area may still be inaccessible due to snow.  There is still considerable snow on sections of the Heather trail, especially on north-facing aspects, and windfall have not yet been cut. Hiking further than First Brother Mountain is not recommended. To help protect this sensitive sub-alpine ecosystem, please stay on designated trails. Please observe temporary one-way trail and physical distancing restrictions to help reduce the spread of COVID-19.

public-advisory.Title: Klappan Rail Grade is impassible
public-advisory.Description: The Klappan Rail grade has suffered a wash out at km 30. Eaglenest Creek Trail and Didene Portage trail are no longer accessible via the Klappan Rail Grade. Access to Spatsizi Plateau Wilderness Provincial Park is possible through air charter or via the McEwan Creek Trail.

public-advisory.Title: Cold Fish Lake Camp facilities closed for the season
public-advisory.Description: All facilities at Cold Fish Lake Camp are closed to visitors for the 2020 season. This decision has been made to ensure the continued health and safety of BC Parks visitors, employees, park contractors, volunteers and partners, and to support efforts to reduce the spread of COVID-19.

public-advisory.Title: This park is no longer closed due to COVID-19
public-advisory.Description:
• There are no facilities, trails, or services in this park.  
    • There is no access to this park due to it being on the West side of the Squamish River.

public-advisory.Title: Conrad Kain hut is CLOSED until further notice due to COVID-19 protocols
Campground and boat launch closed
public-advisory.Description: The campground and boat launch at Pennask Lake Park, at the south east end of Pennask Lake, are closed until further notice due to a hazard tree issue.

public-advisory.Title: This [pType] will begin re-opening on June 29, 2020 with exceptions
public-advisory.Description: Please note all visitors must be self-sufficient as all services in Nisga’a villages will remain closed to the public.

public-advisory.Title: Danger tree removal at Baby Bedwell campsite and Elk River second (upper) campsite on June 29
public-advisory.Description: Work crews will be at Baby Bedwell campsite and Elk River second (upper) campsite on the afternoon of June 29th to clear danger trees. Please be prepared to clear campsite areas while work is taking place. We appreciate your patience; this will ensure your safety in the future.

public-advisory.Title: Public access to the column features is not permitted
public-advisory.Description: Keremeos Columns Park does not contain the geological features that were intended to be protected at the time of establishment in the early 1930s. The column features are fully contained on private land. At this time, public access to the column features is not permitted. Viewing of the column features must be done so by using valley bottom vantage points that do not involve encroachment or access onto private land.

public-advisory.Title: Nisga’a Memorial Lava Bed Park/Anhluut’ukwsim Laxmihl Angwinga’asanskwhl Nisga’a will begin re-opening on June 29, 2020 with exceptions.
public-advisory.Description: Please note all visitors must be self-sufficient as all services in Nisga’a villages will remain closed to the public. This decision has been made to ensure the continued health and safety of First Nations, BC Parks visitors, employees, park contractors, volunteers and partners, and to support efforts to reduce the spread of COVID-19. For more information on protective measures for COVID-19, please visit the website for the BC Centre for Disease Control.

public-advisory.Title: All campsites are 100% reservable. No first-come, first-served sites are available this season.
public-advisory.Note: Need to activate the rank function before enabling this notice. It is currently hard-coded.

public-advisory.Title: Blackwall Road to the Cascade Lookout and the upper Dry Ridge Trail are now open
public-advisory.Description: Blackwall road past the upper Dry Ridge trail and the Heather trail system remain closed to help protect seasonal bear habitat and reduce trail erosion, and will open July 1st provided the road is snow-free.
public-advisory.Note: Currently using the hard-coded notice because of an error on the E.C. Manning page

public-advisory.Title: Blackwall Road to the Cascade Lookout and the upper Dry Ridge Trail are now open
The Lightning Lake campground will be open and available for reservations on June 26
Champion Lakes Provincial Park will be closed starting September 16, 2020 until further notice
public-advisory.Description: The park will be undergoing forest fuel management for wildfire safety. The park will not be safe for public access during this time. The park will reopen for the winter cross country ski season. Thanks for your cooperation.

public-advisory.Title: COVID-19 update
public-advisory.Description: Until further notice, Tweedsmuir Park South is now open for local community day use activities. However, please note that significant concerns around a localized outbreak of COVID -19 exist as remote coastal communities have limited capacity to support the community in case of an outbreak. There is no guarantee that Tweedsmuir South Park will remain open and we appreciate the public’s cooperation to stay within their local communities during these challenging times as per the Provincial Health Officer directives.

public-advisory.Title: Nyrstar Mine Access
public-advisory.Description: To ensure public safety and maintain continued access through the active mine, the public is reminded to be respectful of the mine entrance "Checkpoint", obey all No Entry signs and follow directional signage to park trailheads/parking. Mine site conditions can change rapidly and industrial mine traffic is constantly active. While visitors are safe travelling through the mine along the main road corridor, there is a safety risk if deviating into No Entry areas. Thank you for your cooperation.

public-advisory.Title: Backcountry camping opportunities will remain available for non-B.C. residents accessing this Provincial Park on the Alberta/B.C. border through existing established trail routes or permitted flight services from Alberta.
Access to this [pType] may be restricted
public-advisory.Description: BC Parks is advising potential visitors to this [pType] that local First Nations are in a continued state of emergency due to COVID-19. Visitors may find access to these locations restricted due to roadblocks on lands managed by local First Nations. Most services in these communities remain closed and visitors are being refused entry.

public-advisory.Title: Mabel Lake camping 100% reservable
public-advisory.Description: To ensure a more effective transition from the COVID-19 closure period, Mabel Lake Park will move to 100% reservable camping for the 2020 camping season. Please note that the overflow camping area normally located in the day use will not be available as a camping opportunity.

public-advisory.Title: Exchamsiks River Protected Area is estimated to open at 5:00pm
public-advisory.Description: Hazard tree work is currently underway.

public-advisory.Title: Bridge Failure at Tay Creek
public-advisory.Description: Please be advised the bridge at Tay Creek is impassable until futher notice. BC Parks is working on a solution. Thank you for your patience and understanding.

public-advisory.Title: New for 2019: Reservations available through Discover Camping
public-advisory.Description:
Starting on April 2, 2019, the Fisheries Pool and Atnarko campgrounds at Tweedsmuir Provincial Park South will offer campsite reservations via our Discover Camping reservation service.

Tweedsmuir Provincial Park is currently not accepting reservations or first-come, first-served camping for frontcountry or backcountry

public-advisory.Title: Athabasca River suspension bridge failure
public-advisory.Description: On October 1, 2014, the suspension bridge which crosses the Athabasca River in Jasper National Park, along the land access route to Hamber Park, failed.

public-advisory.Title: This park was burnt over by the 2017 wildfires. The park has now been reopened.
public-advisory.Description:
Caution: be advised that there are significant risks associated with entering areas that have been burnt over by the 2017 wildfires. Potential risks could include:

  • danger trees and overhead hazards – the integrity of trees whose trunks, roots or branches have been damaged by wildfire is unreliable
  • terrain instability resulting in landslides and falling or shifting debris and rock
  • amplified runoff after rainfall or snowmelt which could result in a rapid increase of water course depth and flow rates or flooding conditions
  • ash pits – may be deep and difficult to see
  • respiratory effects caused by breathing soot and charcoal for extended periods of time

Post-wildfire hazards may last for several years or longer after a wildfire and may be triggered at any time with little or no warning.

public-advisory.Title: The Haisla Nation Trapper’s Cabin at the entrance to Brim River has been removed and will not be replaced
Backcountry Reservations
public-advisory.Description: As of February 28, 2017, the Jedediah Island Marine Provincial Park backcountry campground offers backcountry registrations via our Discover Camping Backcountry Registration System.

public-advisory.Title: Access road to Mortar and Pestle Trailhead is washed out
public-advisory.Description: The access road to Mortar and Pestle Trailhead is washed out and impassable by motor vehicles.

public-advisory.Title: Hazard warning - winter road conditions
public-advisory.Description:
Narrow winding mountain road, expect snow, ice and steep grades.
Must use winter tires, must carry chains.

Chains must be installed to access the upper parking lot at Diamond Head (Red Heather, Elfin Lakes), and the parking lot at Rubble Creek (Garibaldi Lake, Taylor Meadows).

Vehicles blocking snow removal equipment on road will be towed at owners’ expense.

Grader requires minimum 20 feet of road width.

Vehicles are advised not to park on Ring Creek Road as they may be subject to Municipal Towing.

Chains are mandatory beyond the chain up area, as per posted signage or direction by park staff.

Failure to comply will result in a $115 fine and or eviction from the park.
